title: Will there be a complex coordinated terrorist attack (CCTA) in the United States either directed or inspired by a foreign terrorist organization before 1 September 2021?
preds: Based on frequency, only 9 days until deadline, and the fact it needs to be complex and coordinated.
Unlikely.  The terrorists are winning without raising a hand. All in.

We will have to gear up, tool up.”" **However, it will take some time for the outcomes of increased terrorism to set in and won't occur before the question closes.

It seems unlikely that another CCTA will occur in the United States (US) before 1 September 2021 for two major reasons: First, COVID-19 creates logistical and planning issues for any terrorist organization that wants to attack the US. The fact that individuals currently can't travel to specific countries and face additional scrutiny when traveling abroad creates roadblocks for these types of attacks [1]. Second, the US has dramatically reduced its presence in the areas of the world where terrorist organizations operate. This reduces the impact of these types of attacks have and won't draw the type of financial/personnel support that terrorist organizations expect to receive after these types of attacks. The US has also issued NOTAM's for countries like Syria that prohibit direct flights to/from the US to those locations which hinders planning/training for attacks inside the US [2]. Finally, I don't believe funding domestic groups falls under the "direct/Inspire" requirement outlined in this question. If you look at all of the examples listed, each one espoused specific grievances aired by foreign terrorist organizations. Domestic terrorist groups (such as those that took part in the Capitol insurrection in early January) have not identified any FTO goals/ideologies that inspired them. Thus, I rate the probability of a directed/inspired FTO CCTA occurring in the US before 1  Sept 2021 at a 0% probability. [1] https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/from-other-countries.html
[2] https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/traveladvisories/syria-travel-advisory.html

On Black Swan Events :https://www.thecipherbrief.com/article/china/are-we-ready-for-another-shock
Black Swans- Black swans” are events that arrive as unwelcome surprises and have significant effects on nations and societies.  They can upend the status quo in politics, economics, or national security. Black swans are even more dangerous when superimposed on other black swans. It’s always worth trying to anticipate potential black swans – indeed, after 9/11 the CIA created a unit, called the Red Cell, to do just that.  But doing so is more necessary today than ever, given what is higher-than-normal fragility in the systems most often affected by these events. Black swans come in two forms.  The first are events that were simply not imagined before they happened, such as al-Qaeda using airplanes as guided missiles on 9/11 or the Russians using our own social media as a tool to attack our democracy in 2016.  The second type are those seen as possible but were discounted as being highly unlikely, such as the current pandemic.  Black swans can be domestic, such as Hurricane Katrina and its devastation of New Orleans, or foreign, such as Russia’s 2014 invasion of Crimea. While surprises, black swans occur with enough frequency to be able to predict that others could easily occur between now and the inauguration next January of either a second term for President Trump or a first term for former Vice President Biden.  As we survey the foreign landscape, which is where our expertise lies, we see several potential, near-term black swans. One would be a Chinese move against Taiwan. In his recent article in the National Interest, Graham Allison of Harvard’s Kennedy School outlines the many parallels between today and the period leading up to the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, as well as some of the actions China might use to achieve this long-standing goal of bringing Taiwan under its control. In addition to capitalizing on current distractions in the U.S., Beijing could see three reasons for moving now.  Taiwan, under the leadership of President Tsai Ing-wen, is moving further away from Beijing; Hong Kong as a model for Taiwan of a “one state, two systems” is collapsing; and the U.S. has just made clear that it wants to deny China one of the products that it imports and desperately needs, semiconductors.  China obtains many of its semiconductors from Taiwan. China’s leadership, which tries to avoid the kind of international condemnation such a move would bring, could well view action against Taiwan as worth it, especially if Beijing calculates that the price would be ultimately mitigated given China’s growing economic power and the resulting tendency of nations to forget Chinese misdeeds when doing so is in their interest. China’s intent would be to bring Taiwan under its political control without firing a shot. China’s actions would commence in the so-called gray zone and escalate incrementally.  Early actions would include economic pressure, covert political interference ranging from disinformation operations to organizing street protests in Taiwan and buying political influence there.  Beijing would leverage the threat of force, most likely through a well-timed military exercise, but would actually use it only if necessary and if victory were nearly certain. Any U.S. administration would have a hard-enough time making decisions on how to respond to such a crisis in normal times, but it would be far more difficult in the midst of a competitive election campaign superimposed on multiple ongoing crises.  Even if the Trump Administration decided to come to Taiwan’s defense, a military move against Taiwan would be difficult to prevent given China’s symmetric and asymmetric military advances, the advantage of initiative, and the tyranny of distance the U.S. military would have to overcome to counter it. Whether the U.S. acts or not, “losing Taiwan” would be a blow.  Although the U.S. has no formal security treaty with Taiwan, and other regional powers would steer well clear of such a crisis, the U.S. is widely seen as the ultimate guarantor of Taiwanese security.  U.S. credibility, therefore, would take a significant hit, from which it would be difficult to recover. Another potential black swan in the months ahead would be a significant, even catastrophic, direct attack by ISIS in the U.S. conducted either by operatives sent here or by ISIS-organized, radicalized individuals already here.  The group is on the rebound in Iraq and Syria, fueled by a drawdown in coalition forces, COVID-related disruptions to Iraqi security services, and the continued marginalization of Sunnis in Iraq. ISIS attacks in Iraq are on the upswing.  There were over 550 ISIS attacks in Iraq in just the first quarter of this year.  Outside the Middle East, German authorities in mid-April arrested four Turkmen citizens who were allegedly planning attacks on U.S. military facilities.  The four were in contact with senior ISIS officials in both Iraq and Afghanistan. They had already purchased weapons and were in the process of acquiring explosives. ISIS may well have learned from al-Qaida in the Arabian Peninsula (AQAP) that, with a little creativity, it is possible to get operatives into the U.S.  AQAP did so by directing an operative to join the Saudi military as a pilot, where they knew he would likely be trained in the U.S.  The result was an attack last year at the Naval Air Station in Pensacola, Florida that killed three. A major ISIS attack in the U.S. just over a year after it officially lost its caliphate in the Middle East would shake the U.S. public, which believes a major attack here is no longer possible.  It would also allow the group to attract new recruits and money and to reinvigorate its online messaging that was such a significant part of its threat to the West. A third potential black swan could be a crippling debt crisis occurring simultaneously in many emerging markets.  These nations, with their high growth rates and dependence on trade, are important players in the global economy.  Entering the pandemic, they were already highly leveraged – with public and private debt at 170 percent of GDP – and their economies were slowing.  Now, because they lack the tools to deal effectively with the health and economic effects of COVID, their need for capital is rising at the same time their debts are coming due.  Argentina has already defaulted on its sovereign debt, and India’s debt is nearing junk status. Because most emerging market debt is owed to western governments and financial institutions, should a number of emerging markets default at the same time, the consequences for the U.S. could be severe, deepening and lengthening our own economic downturn.  It could even lead to a financial crisis here at home. Other overseas black swans that are conceivable in the next few months include: severe political unrest in nuclear-armed Pakistan, which is being ravaged by the coronavirus, that results in the emergence of an extremist government there; economic and political collapse in Mexico, which is also struggling with COVID, that leads to a surge in illegal immigration into the U.S; and North Korea’s current ratcheting up of pressure on South Korea, because the North is dissatisfied that it has not received more tangible benefits from an earlier warming of bilateral relations, that results in some sort of military action that impacts U.S. troops on the Peninsula. Finally, it goes without saying that severe political turbulence occurring in the United States this fall could yield yet another black swan, with truly catastrophic consequences.  Such a crisis could result from impulsive foreign policy decisions – including unwise use of force – made in order to distract the electorate from bad health or economic news or increased unrest in our streets due to a failure to tangibly address the issues underlying ongoing social distress. Or it could be caused by a disputed election outcome, spawned by any of a number of fragilities in existing state and local voting systems, that could not only require rapid and controversial judicial resolution, but – much worse – could result in violence on our own streets. The latter could conceivably remove the last shred of confidence the ambitious peoples of our broader world have in the American experiment. All of these scenarios would be aggravated by a resurgence of the novel coronavirus pandemic, which is starting to feel increasingly likely.  We’re not predicting that any of these black swans will actually occur, but both their likelihood and potential impact seems higher given the distracting political, economic, and health issues currently causing such turbulence in the U.S. More importantly, we point them out as a cautionary note – that wisdom and resiliency in society, economics, and security becomes especially important at such a fragile time.  What else is out there that we have not imagined? Michael Morell, Former Acting Director, CIA Michael Morell was a career intelligence officer.  He served as deputy director and twice acting director of the CIA from 2010 to 2103.  Admiral Sandy Winnefeld (Ret.), Former Vice Chairman, Joint Chiefs of Staff Sandy Winnefeld was a career Navy officer.  He served as the ninth Vice Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff from 2011 to 2015.

Good overview on terrorist attacks in the U.S. in 2020 (or rather, lack thereof) : "So far, we’ve seen no foreign jihadist attacks on U.S. soil, and despite the grim headlines, the actual number of deaths from white supremacists and other domestic terrorists is small ... Data from the New America Foundation shows that zero Americans died from jihadist attacks in the United States this year. For 2020 so far, New America tallies eight terrorism deaths on U.S. soil, far fewer than the 30 Americans killed in 2019 ... Of course, 2020 could be an outlier year. Terrorists regularly plot, and sometimes they are caught and sometimes they succeed ... In 2000 and 2002, there were zero and four deaths, respectively. In 2001, there were 3,005 ... But U.S. policy has also played a role ... U.S. drone attacks and a global intelligence effort, among other lower-profile measures, have decimated the senior leadership of Islamic militant groups. In response, the jihadist movement has localized, focusing on civil wars in the Muslim world and spreading in to new areas in Africa, instead of coordinated attacks on the West." https://www.brookings.edu/blog/order-from-chaos/2020/12/24/2020-appears-to-be-a-good-year-for-counterterrorism/ Note to self: There are 8 full months left in the time frame for this question. Another indication that Islamic extremism, which is by far the most likely source of a CCTA in the U.S. directed/inspired by a foreign terrorist organization, continues to decline: according to the IEP’s new 2020 Global Terrorism Index report, "In 2019, deaths from terrorism fell for the fifth consecutive year, after peaking in 2014 ... ISIL’s strength and influence continued to decline ... The number of terrorist attacks attributed to the group [ISIL] also fell to the lowest level since it was formed, with 339 incidents attributed to the group in 2019." https://www.visionofhumanity.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/GTI-2020-web-1.pdf Revising down to 4% from 5% on the basis of this report and the passage of time.

Based on my analysis of the companion question (CCTAs overall) I estimated 85%. However, analysis of terror attacks show that the vast majority are domestic - usually driven by right-wing groups in the US. (UMD’s analysis of their GTD dataset found in a key finding that “the vast majority of terrorist attacks, including those attributed to organizations that represent the most serious foreign threat to the US, mostly attack domestic targets in their own countries”) In addition, the ongoing COVID crisis has made travel and coordination difficult as well as distracting from international issues as each country focuses on the crisis at home. This makes both inspiring and directing attacks more difficult. As a result, I’m rating the odds here as very low, especially for a coordinated attack. I believe there is about a 3% chance that any given CCTA would be inspired or directed by a foreign terrorist organization at this point; 3% of 85% is 2.55%, so I’ll go with 2% odds overall for the joint probability (rounding down for conservatism due to COVID/etc.)
I think the risk is de minimus and am watching for factors that would move my forecast in the other direction.

With the travel restrictions due to the pandemic, it is very unlikely that a foreign terrorist organization is able to launch as CCTA in the United States.  The FTOs are able to launch in other countries, such as in Europe (due to less restriction in border control), but no in the US.

Historically, homegrown far-right extremism poses the biggest threat to the US. From 1990-2019, when you include 9/11 there have been 47 events in the US motivated by Islamist extremism in the US. During that same period, according to the FBI website, 333 targets were either foiled or failed in the US. This means on average, there are roughly 16.5 terrorist attempts in the US. Given limited travel due to COVID, reduction in travel from Arab countries, and crackdown on the southern boarder, the likeliness of a terror attack is even less than before.
foreign terrorist organizations are on the ropes and the US is less of a target than it was 20 years ago.  Domestic terrorism is much more likely.

The qualification for FTO is probably the most difficult part of this. It's possible Antifa or some fringe domestic militia initiate violence that accounts for all the other requirements, but why would a FTO not just fund or flame or own internal strife, at this moment?  The base rate of terrorism that would meet these requirements within the US must be lower than 1% (I haven't gathered data, but one could argue that these have certainly been increasing since 9/11/2001.)  The crowd forecast being 5% probably represents most forecasters need to find 'flat' numbers, as 10% seems far too high but below 5 seems unreasonable to many. 5% is still too high.

Of the 13 complex coordinated terrorist attacks (CCTAs) that have occurred since 1990 (see my more detailed post for this question's sister question at [1]), there are five that have been either directed or inspired by a foreign terrorist organization (FTO) as designated by the US Department of State [2]. 
— February 26, 1993: World Trade Center bombing...https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1993_World_Trade_Center_bombing (FTO: al-Qa’ida)
— September 11, 2001: September 11 attacks...https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/September_11_attacks (directed by FTO al-Qa’ida)
— April 15, 2013: Boston Marathon bombing...https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston_Marathon_bombing (inspired by FTO al-Qa’ida)
— May 3, 2015: Curtis Culwell Center attack...https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curtis_Culwell_Center_attack (directed by FTO Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant)
— December 2, 2015: San Bernardino attack...https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2015_San_Bernardino_attack (inspired by FTO Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant) Base rate: 5 CCTAs in the past 30 years, 4 of which have occurred in distinct years (two occurred in 2015). 4/30 = 0.13 probability of at least one CCTA in any given year. Inside view: Adjust downward by about half (down by 7%). All of the CCTAs inspired/directed by FTOs in the US since 1990 are related to Jihadist terrorism. Jihadism has declined since its recent peak in 2015 — "The rise of ISIS has brought an unprecedented surge in terrorism cases ... As the years have passed since the peak of ISIS' influence [circa 2015], the number of terrorism cases has declined." [3] I don't see any immediate basis for another uptick in Jihadist terrorism. Final: 6%. This is in solid agreement with the current crowd forecast (5%). [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1132209
[2] https://www.state.gov/foreign-terrorist-organizations/
[3] https://www.newamerica.org/in-depth/terrorism-in-america/part-i-overview-terrorism-cases-2001-today/

It isn't very possible, to plan a complex coordinated terrorist attack in the United States. The whole Staff of Security Offices are doing a good Job. But.... surprises are also possible. Who are interested in confusing the USA? The trend is to confuse by Social Media or by Internet. A lot of terrorism organisations got talented IT- Specialists, everybody knows.
Crowd forecast currently 4%. Unfortunately, attacking USA is a good way to get attention. Starting off at 15%. It’s unlikely - but you rarely know until it happens.
Not unless Covid 19 goes away suddenly.

Re-evaluating: San Bernadino, Boston, 911, maybe the first world trade center booming? We'll call it 3.5 /30 years. So the base rate is 11.6ish. Feel to me like local civil unrest and pandemic creat at least a short term reduction in the likelihood of international terrorism directed at the US, so I'm going to drop that number a little due to gut feel.

Thes events are few and far between. Additionally, there has not been significant externally driven terrorism since 2017. That being said, a lot of externally driven terrorism depends on what is happening outside of the country. As events unfold this could change. Especially if the US engages in significant conflict elsewhere.

Same rationale as the other (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1130148) but limited to foreign influence. Of that list only 9/11 and I believe San Bernadino would count. San Bernadino is unclear though because according to wikipedia it sounds like they were inspired by foreign terrorist organizations but not directly connected to them in any way. I don't know how that would be judged. I'm going to subjectively go with 2% as there's a chance but it appears very small and a 1 in 50 year event sounds about right.

When I read the wording of the question "[...]or inspired by a foreign terrorist organization[...]", I think of the possibility that Israel's annexation of Palestinian land finally takes places and will be backed by the current WH admin (POTUS 45, influenced by his son in law), and that this might "inspire" some cells in the US to attempt to send a signal of retaliation to the US and the world. However, the options for doing so have become slimmer under the massive frictionless surveillance.
The linked list, at least, reads like the "Who is who" in the Palestinian armed fight for independence, recognition, and statehood. If the US should happen to attack Iran (which I feel is rather likely), then the same goes for people with a pathological sympathy for Iran. So in conclusion, I view the likelihood as non-zero here too, and, as already the annotations mention, by design the typical attack of this kind will come and be  "initiated with little or no warning" [3].
